required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Measuring Signatures in the Fluid Surrounding the Spinal Cord in Patients Who Have Problems With Intrathecal Drug Delivery
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility of Measuring Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Signatures in Subjects With Intrathecal Catheter-Related Problems

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to record signatures from the fluid surrounding the spinal cord from people who have an implanted drug infusion system.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this feasibility study is to record cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) signatures from subjects who have an implanted drug infusion system and who undergo clinical tests designed to troubleshoot possible catheter-related problems as part of their normal standard of care. Signatures will be correlated with physician-determined catheter status.

primary_outcome.measure: Classification of Catheter Function by CSF Signatures vs. Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
primary_outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, CSF signatures recorded in subjects who have an infusion system who present with signs and/or symptoms of possible catheter-related problems or failure.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Relationship Between Catheter Flow Resistance Check Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
secondary_outcome.description: Characterize the relationship between pressure decay-to-baseline time (in seconds) and the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis

secondary_outcome.measure: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Cough
secondary_outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a cough

secondary_outcome.measure: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Valsalva
secondary_outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a valsalva maneuver

study_pop.textblock: Subjects with implanted Medtronic drug infusion system for chronic intrathecal administration, and who report decreased therepeutic benefit or who present with visible signs and/or symptoms of decreased therapeutic benefit, suggesting possible catheter-related problems.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Be at least 12 years of age
- Have an implanted Medtronic drug infusion system for chronic intrathecal administration of drugs
- Report decreased therapeutic benefit, or show visible signs and/or symptoms of decreased therapeutic benefit
- Agree to undergo clinical tests designed to troubleshoot catheter-related problems or failure as a part of their normal standard of care
- Agree to provide signed informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Are currently enrolled or plan to enroll in another investigational drug or device trial
- Have participated in an investigational drug or device study within 30 days of the in-clinic visit
- Whose health status would, in the opinion of the Clinical Investigator, be jeopardized by participation in the study

reference.citation: Coffey RJ, Miesel K, Billstrom T. Cerebrospinal fluid pressure measurement in the ovine intrathecal space: a preliminary study towards the diagnosis of intrathecal drug administration catheter dislodgement or occlusion. Stereotact Funct Neurosurg. 2010;88(6):337-44. doi: 10.1159/000319034. Epub 2010 Aug 21.

results_reference.citation: Saulino M, Miesel K, Turner M, Cochran F, Stromberg K, Fehrmann E, Markert M. Can CSF pressure signals distinguish catheter complications from normal catheter function in subjects who experience loss of intrathecal baclofen therapy? Abstract submitted to the 11th World Congress of the International Neuromodulation Society (June 2013; Berlin).

Saulino M, Turner M, Miesel K, Cochran FR, Stromberg K, Fehrmann E, Markert M, Spencer R. Can Cerebrospinal Fluid Pressure Detect Catheter Complications in Patients Who Experience Loss of Effectiveness With Intrathecal Baclofen Therapy? Neuromodulation. 2017 Feb;20(2):187-197. doi: 10.1111/ner.12471. Epub 2016 Aug 1.

group.title: Intrathecal Pump Patients
group.description: Subjects previously implanted with an intrathecal pump who satisfied all inclusion and exclusion criteria, provided written informed consent, and had a needle inserted into the catheter access port of the implanted pump were considered to be enrolled in the study

group.title: Intrathecal Pump Patients
group.description: Subjects who satisfied all inclusion and exclusion criteria, provided written informed consent, and had a needle inserted into the catheter access port of the implanted pump were considered to be enrolled in the study

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Infusion system spasticity treatment sub-indication
measure.description: The primary treatment indication for all subjects was severe spasticity. This measure describes the treatment sub-indication for each subject.

outcome.title: Classification of Catheter Function by CSF Signatures vs. Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, CSF signatures recorded in subjects who have an infusion system who present with signs and/or symptoms of possible catheter-related problems or failure.
outcome.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, or if there was an issue with the equipment

group.title: Subjects With Normal Catheter Function by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data were analyzable and who received a trouble-shooting diagnosis of normal catheter function from the physician

group.title: Subjects With Catheter Complications by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data were analyzable and who received a trouble-shooting diagnosis of catheter complication from the physician

measure.title: Classification of Catheter Function by CSF Signatures vs. Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
measure.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, CSF signatures recorded in subjects who have an infusion system who present with signs and/or symptoms of possible catheter-related problems or failure.
measure.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, or if there was an issue with the equipment
measure.units: Subjects whose CSF data agree with MD Dx

outcome.title: The Relationship Between Catheter Flow Resistance Check Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
outcome.description: Characterize the relationship between pressure decay-to-baseline time (in seconds) and the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis
outcome.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, if the clamp was not open, or if the resistance check data were missing.

group.title: Subjects With Normal Catheter Function by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose catheter flow resistance check data were analyzable and who received a trouble-shooting diagnosis of normal catheter function from the physician

group.title: Subjects With Catheter Complications by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose catheter flow resistance check data were analyzable and who received a trouble-shooting diagnosis of catheter complication from the physician

measure.title: The Relationship Between Catheter Flow Resistance Check Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis
measure.description: Characterize the relationship between pressure decay-to-baseline time (in seconds) and the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis
measure.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, if the clamp was not open, or if the resistance check data were missing.

outcome.title: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Cough
outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a cough
outcome.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, or if the subject was unable to cough.

group.title: Subjects With Normal Catheter Function by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data in response to cough were analyzable and who received a diagnosis of normal catheter function from the physician

group.title: Subjects With Catheter Complications by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data in response to cough were analyzable and who received a diagnosis of catheter complication from the physician

measure.title: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Cough
measure.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a cough
measure.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, or if the subject was unable to cough.

outcome.title: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Valsalva
outcome.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a valsalva maneuver
outcome.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, if the subject was unable to perform the valsalva, or if data were missing.

group.title: Subjects With Normal Catheter Function by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data in response to valsalva were analyzable and who received a diagnosis of normal catheter function from the physician

group.title: Subjects With Catheter Complications by Physician Diagnosis
group.description: Subjects whose pressure data in response to valsalva were analyzable and who received a diagnosis of catheter complication from the physician

measure.title: The Relationship Between CSF Pressure Data and Physician's Standard Trouble-shooting Diagnosis During Physical Task Protocol: Valsalva
measure.description: Collect and characterize, by comparison with the physician's standard trouble-shooting diagnosis, the mean change in CSF pressure data during the physical task of a valsalva maneuver
measure.population: Subjects were excluded if the needle was not in the CAP, if they had a ventricular catheter, if the pressure sensor malfunctioned, if there was an issue with the equipment, if the subject was unable to perform the valsalva, or if data were missing.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were recorded throughout this research study, from time of subject enrollment to subject discontinuation. The minimum duration of subject follow-up was 47 days; the maximum was 287 days.
reported_events.desc: All adverse events were collected for the duration of the study. No adverse events were associated with the measurement of CSF pressure energy, including insertion of the needle into the CAP and subsequent data acquisition lasting 6.3 ± 2.9 minutes (mean ± SD).

group.title: Intrathecal Pump Patients
group.description: Subjects who satisfied all inclusion and exclusion criteria, provided written informed consent, and had a needle inserted into the catheter access port of the implanted pump were considered to be enrolled in the study

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: "Normal" subjects who received intrathecal baclofen without experiencing catheter complications were not enrolled. Subjects who received intrathecal drug delivery for chronic pain were not enrolled. This was not a longitudinal study.

point_of_contact.organization: Medtronic Restorative Therapies Group - Targeted Drug Delivery
